notes: irregular verb; past participle 'potuto'; auxiliary avere
example_sentence_english: I would like to be able to come.
Not being able to speak, I wrote.

notes: past participle; agrees when required; auxiliary avere
example_sentence_english: I was able to do it.
The suitcase? I was able to lift it.
We were able to help them.
I was able to use them.
I can help you.
You can come.
He can help.
We can go.
You (plural) can enter.
They can come.
As a child I could run fast.
You could have done it earlier.
She could have chosen differently.
We could see the sea.
You (plural) could come yesterday.
They could help.
If I could, I would do it.
If you could, what would you do?
I hope he could explain.
If we could, we would change everything.

notes: imperfect subjunctive; used in subordinate clauses and contrary-to-fact conditions
example_sentence_english: If you could come, it would be fantastic.
If they could, they would help.

notes: used with auxiliary avere; past participle 'potuto'
example_sentence_english: I was able to finish the work.
Have you been able to find the keys?

translation_english: he has been able to/she has been able to/you (formal) have been able to
example_sentence_english: He was able to help me yesterday.
We were able to solve the problem.
Have you (plural) been able to talk to him?
They were able to attend the meeting.
